title: 114_hr2320
content: The Act titled "Federal Improper Payments Coordination Act of 2015" allows the Do Not Pay Initiative to be accessible to the judicial and legislative branches and states. Section 5 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to allow States, contractors, subcontractors, and agents of States, as well as the judicial and legislative branches of the United States, access to the Do Not Pay Initiative for verifying payment eligibility. The Do Not Pay Initiative is established for States, contractors, subcontractors, and agents of States, as well as the judicial and legislative branches of the United States, with oversight by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to ensure compliance with the Privacy Act of 1974. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue guidance establishing privacy requirements for the Do Not Pay Initiative access agreements with States, contractors, subcontractors, agents, and the judicial and legislative branches of the United States. This guidance may also include States, quasi-government entities, and their judicial and legislative branches. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue guidance establishing privacy requirements for the Do Not Pay Initiative access agreements with States, contractors, subcontractors, agents, and the judicial and legislative branches of the United States, including entities defined in section 202(e) of title 18, United States Code. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to improve the sharing and use of data by government agencies to curb improper payments. This includes updating death records maintained by the Commissioner of Social Security and enhancing the use of data by government agencies for this purpose. The Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense must promptly report death information to relevant agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance on data access for preventing improper payments. The Do Not Pay Initiative will be implemented by relevant agencies, including the Department of the Treasury and agencies operating databases or needing improved data matching. Guidance will address implementation and set deadlines. The Do Not Pay Initiative will establish deadlines for access to and use of databases under section 5(a)(2). SEC. 4. DATA ANALYTICS. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Federal Improper Payments Coordination Act of 2015. The report will detail data analytics conducted by the Do Not Pay Business Center to detect, prevent, and recover improper payments. This includes analysis of payments and beneficiary enrollment lists of State programs. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct data analytics to identify improper payments by reviewing beneficiary enrollment lists, comparing data across Federal agencies, and analyzing other relevant information. The effectiveness of these efforts will be measured using specific metrics. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct data analytics to reduce improper payments or awards and implement data analytics operations as part of the Do Not Pay Business Center.
